Smatresk]]{{cite web|title=About Neal Smatresk|url=http://go.unlv.edu/president/about|work=Office of the President|publisher=UNLV|accessdate=3 July 2011}} |vice-presid ent = |provost = Michael Bowers |vice_chancellor = |head_label = |head = |faculty = 1,000 |staff = 3,282 |students = 28,203 (Fall 2010){{cite web|title=Facts and stats|url=http://go.unlv.edu/about/glance/facts|work=About UNLV|publisher=UNLV|accessdate=3 July 2011}} |undergrad = 22,708 (Fall 2010) |postgrad = 6,378 (Fall 2010) |other = |city = [[Paradise, Nevada|Paradise]] |state = [[Nevada]] |province = |country = U.S. |coor = {{Coord|36.10779|N|115.14376|W|source:placeopedia_type:edu|display=title}} |campus = Urban
Main Campus: {{convert|337|acre|km2|abbr=on}}
North Campus: {{convert|640|acre|km2|abbr=on}}
Shadow Lane Campus: {{convert|18.2|acre|abbr=on}} |former_names = Nevada Southern University (1965-69), University of Nevada, Southern Division
(1957-65) |free_label = |free = |sports = 17 Varsity teams |colors = [[Scarlet (color)|Scarlet]] and [[Grey (color)|gray]] {{color box|#C10202}} {{color box|#666666}} |colours = |nickname = [[UNLV Rebels|Rebels]] |mascot = Hey Reb |athletics = [[NCAA Division I]] - [[Football Bowl Subdivision|FBS]]
[[Mountain West Conference]] |affiliations = |website = [http://www.unlv.edu unlv.edu] |logo = [[File:UNLV Logo.svg|210px]] |footnotes = }} '''University of Nevada-Las Vegas''' ('''UNLV''') is a [[state university (U.S.)|public]], [[co-education|coeducational]] [[university]] located in the [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] suburb of [[Paradise, Nevada]], [[United States of America|USA]]. The {{convert|337|acre|km2|sing=on}} [[campus]] is located approximately {{convert|1.5|mi}} east of the [[Las Vegas Strip]]. The institution includes a Shadow Lane Campus, located just east of the [[University Medical Center of Southern Nevada]]. The [[university]] has been deemed a "research-intensive university" by [[The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching]]. ==History== The first [[college]] classes which would eventually become the classes of UNLV were offered as the southern regional extension division of the [[University of Nevada, Reno|University of Nevada]] in 1951 in a classroom at [[Las Vegas High School]]. Groundbreaking on the original{{convert|60|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} site was in April 1956, and the university purchased a {{convert|640|acre|km2|abbr=on|sing=on}} site in [[North Las Vegas, Nevada|North Las Vegas]] for future expansion. UNLV was officially founded by the [[Nevada System of Higher Education|Nevada Board of Regents]] as the Southern Division of the [[University of Nevada, Reno|University of Nevada]] in 1957. The first classes were held on the current campus in the [[post and beam]] [[Mid Century Modern]] [[Maude Frazier]] Hall designed by the [[award]] winning local [[architectural]] firm, [http://www.library.unlv.edu/arch/architects/zickandsharpresources.html Zick and Sharp]. Twenty-nine [[students]] [[graduated]] in the first commencement ceremonies in 1964.{{cite news|title=Sawyer Lauds Local Campus At Graduation|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/1964/jun/04/sawyer-lauds-local-campus-graduation/?framing=history|accessdate=21 November 2011|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|date=4 June 1964}} {{cite web|title=Timeline|url=http://go.unlv.edu/history/timeline|work=UNLV history|publisher=UNLV|accessdate=3 July 2011}} In 1965, the Nevada Legislature named the school '''Nevada Southern University''', and the Board of Regents hired the campus's first [[president]], Donald C. Moyer.{{cite web|title=Past presidents & campus leaders|url=http://go.unlv.edu/history/presidents|work=UNLV|accessdate=26 June 2011}} In 1968, Nevada Southern was given equal status with its parent institution in [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]], and the present name was approved by the Regents in January 1969, during a winter session and without input by representatives from the [[University of Nevada, Reno|University of Nevada]] . During this time Nevada Southern University also adopted the southern "Rebel" athletics moniker and a mascot dressed in a southern Confederate uniform named Beauregard. The popular reasoning behind such a controversial moniker and mascot is that they did it to oppose the northern Union traditions and symbols of their northern rival, the University of Nevada. It was not long, however, before protests from NSU/UNLV students forced a slight change to their Confederate mascot, but the "Rebels" moniker remains to this day. Since its founding, the university has grown rapidly, expanding both its academic programs and campus facilities. In 1969, the Board of Regents approved the new name of University of Nevada at Las Vegas and the abbreviation UNLV. In 1973 [[Jerry Tarkanian]] was hired as the men's basketball coach by UNLV's second president, Roman Zorn.{{cite news|title=UNLVâs pioneering second president, Zorn, dies at 85|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2002/aug/20/unlvs-pioneering-second-president-zorn-dies-at-85/|accessdate=19 November 2011|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|date=20 August 2002}} In 1981 [[Claes Oldenburg]]'s Flashlight sculpture was installed on the plaza between Artemus Ham Hall and Judy Bayley Theatre.{{cite news|last=Arin|first=Naomi|title=High beam: Using a flashlight to illuminate the public art struggles of âPaintbrushesâ|url=http://weeklyseven.com/ae/2011/march/17/high-beam|accessdate=21 November 2011|newspaper=Vegas Seven|date=17 March 2011}} In 2004, UNLV opened its first regional campus on Shadow Lane, near the University Medical Center. The School of Dental Medicine is located on the Shadow Lane Campus. ===New initiatives=== In 2005, the university received over $95 million in extramural research funding, about a 30 percent increase over the previous year. Its fund raising campaign, "Invent the Future", reached its $500 million goal in 2009.{{cite news|last=Richmond|first=Emily|title=Success: UNLV hits mark of $500 million in cash and pledges|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/nov/05/unlv-celebrates-500-million-goal-reached-fundraisi/|accessdate=15 September 2011|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|date=5 November 2009}} In 2009, a $59.7 million Advanced Clinical and Research Training Center was constructed under architect Carpenter Sellers. This LEED equivalent building is expected to be completed by summer 2010. It will serve to consolidate the University of Nevada Health Sciences System programs through the shared use of classrooms, teaching labs, and simulated patient lab space.http://csdarchitecture.com/project/unlv-advanced-clinical-training-and-research-center ===Sustainability=== The University of Nevada, Las Vegas has created an Urban Sustainability Initiative that strives to implement sustainable practices both on campus and in the larger Las Vegas community.{{cite web|title=Urban Sustainability Initiative|publisher=University of Nevada - Las Vegas|url=http://urban21.unlv.edu/|accessdate=2008-05-28}} In addition to having two campus buildings in the process of [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] Silver Certification and one building in the process of LEED Gold Certification, UNLV has reduced its use of electricity and natural gas by 38 percent per square foot since 2001 by retrofitting older campus buildings.{{cite web|title=Urban Sustainability Initiative Campus Efforts|publisher=University of Nevada - Las Vegas|url=http://urban21.unlv.edu/about/efforts.html|accessdate=2008-05-28}} In the 2009 edition of the Sustainable Endowment Instituteâs College Sustainability Report Card, University of Nevada-Las Vegas received a grade of "C".{{cite web|title=College Sustainability Report Card 2008|publisher=Sustainable Endowments Institute|url=http://www.greenreportcard.org/report-card-2009/schools/university-of-nevadalas-vegas|accessdate=2008-05-28}} In an effort to stop or at least reduce the budget cuts to UNLV and the rest of the [[Nevada System of Higher Education]] (NSHE), rallies were held early 2009 to protest the situation.http://savenevadastudents.org/ Tuition will be raised by 10% for fall 2009 as a partial measure to alleviate Nevada's financial hardship.http://www.rgj.com/article/20090620/NEWS/906200339/1321/news Resources and amenities aiding students in their research and learning may be cut. Faculty and staff are also affected by Nevada's budget shortfalls. They remain worried about pay cuts, lost benefits, and job security.http://system.nevada.edu/Initiative/Proposed-B/Budget-Cut/04.28.09_Faculty-Recruitment---Reten.pdf ==Academics== {{Infobox US university ranking |USNWR_NU=Tier 2 |USNWR_LA= |USNWR_Bus=NR |USNWR_Law=75 |USNWR_Medr= |USNWR_Medc= |USNWR_Eng= |USNWR_Ed=NR |USNWR_Fine Arts=81 |ARWU_W= |ARWU_N= |ARWU_SCI= |ARWU_ENG= |ARWU_LIFE= |ARWU_MED= |ARWU_SOC= |THES_W= |THES_N= |CMUP= |Wamo_NU=166 |Forbes=393 }} UNLV offers over 200 programs of study in varying fields leading to [[bachelor's degree|bachelor's]], [[master's degree|master's]], and [[doctorate]] degrees, which are taught by approximately 850 faculty members. Notable departments include the [[UNLV School of Architecture|School of Architecture]], [[UNLV School of Dental Medicine|School of Dental Medicine]], [[UNLV College of Education|College of Education]], [[UNLV Graduate College|Graduate College]], [[William F. Harrah College of Hotel Administration]], [[William S. Boyd School of Law]], and [http://engineering.unlv.edu/ Howard R. Hughes College of Engineering] [[The Atlantic]] Monthly recognized UNLV's [[English language|English Department]] as having one of the nation's most innovative [[Master of Fine Arts]] programs and one of the top five [[doctoral]] programs in [[creative writing]].{{cite news|last=Littlefield|first=Christina|title=UNLV programs getting it âwriteâ|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2007/aug/02/unlv-programs-getting-it-write/|accessdate=15 September 2011|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|date=2 August 2007}} [[Down Beat]] Magazine, the internationally recognized industry standard trade publication for jazz music, recognized the work of the 2010 UNLV Jazz Ensemble as "Outstanding Large Jazz Ensemble Performance" among graduate college-level jazz bands in their annual Student Music Award issue of that year.Las Vegas Jazz Society, "[http://vegasjazz.org/Press%20Release%20UNLV%20JAZZ%20Award.pdf]," (accessed May 21, 2010) In 2006, UNLV opened its first [[international]] campus in [[Singapore]]. The UNLV Singapore campus is housed on the 10th and 11th floors of the [[National Library of Singapore]], a prestigious building comparable to the [[United States Library of Congress]]. The campus offers [[bachelorâs degree]] programs in Hotel Administration and Hospitality Management. UNLV Singapore is offering the college's upper division courses, which include Hotel Administration, Hospitality Marketing, Food & Beverage Management and Hotel Law. Students may also earn an executive master's degree in hospitality.http://www.unlv.edu.sg/website/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12&Itemid=130 An elementary school, Paradise Professional Development School, is located on campus and operated as a partnership between UNLV and the Clark County School District.{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kristen|title=Last bell rings for Paradise|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/1998/jun/05/last-bell-rings-for-paradise/|accessdate=19 November 2011|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|date=5 June 1998}} ==Campus== [[Image:StripFromUNLV.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Las Vegas Strip]] can be seen in the distance from various points on the UNLV campus]] The main campus of UNLV is located on a 332 acre land granthttp://www.unlv.edu/about/ in centrally located Paradise, Nevada. ''Midtown UNLV'' is an ongoing private-public development along Maryland Parkway, a border street to the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. Development began in 2002 and the purpose is to expand the university to meet the demands of a major university in the [[Las Vegas metropolitan area]]. The project is designed to improve the "front door" of the University by improving amenities for students and businesses along Maryland Parkway. The goals are to reduce vacant spaces, lower business turnover rates, as well as create new space for the University to expand. Additionally, the project aims to create new housing developments close to campus. Major funding is through state funding sources along with private donations.http://midtown.unlv.edu/about.html ===Buildings=== Performing arts facilities include the Judy Bayley Theatre (1972), the Artemus W. Ham Concert Hall (1976), the Black Box Theatre, the Alta Ham Fine Arts Complex (1982), and the Lee and Thomas Beam Music Center (2001).{{cite book|last=Moehring|first=Eugene|title=The University of Nevada, Las Vegas: a history|year=2007|publisher=University of Nevada Press|location=Reno, NV|isbn=087417709X|pages=392}} Athletic facilities include [[Sam Boyd Stadium]], [[Thomas & Mack Center]](1983){{cite news|last=Weatherford|first=Mike|title=Arena celebration|url=http://www.lvrj.com/neon/21958279.html|accessdate=19 November 2011|newspaper=Las Vegas Review Journal|date=27 June 2008}} , [[Cox Pavilion]], and [[Earl Wilson Stadium]]. In 1997 the [[UNLV School of Architecture|Paul B. Sogg Architecture Building]] opened. In 2001, The {{convert|301000|sqft|m2|adj=on}}, $58 million [[Lied Library]], named for real estate entrepreneur Ernst W. Lied, opened. A new {{convert|135000|sqft|abbr=on}} [[student activity center|student union]] and a new {{convert|188000|sqft|abbr=on}} [http://srwc.unlv.edu/ recreation center] were both completed in 2007.http://facilities.unlv.edu/plancon/student-union.htmlhttp://facilities.unlv.edu/plancon/rec.html ==Athletics== [[Image:Thomas&MackCenterAndCoxPavilion.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Thomas & Mack Center]] and adjoining [[Cox Pavilion]] house many of the university's athletic teams.]] {{Main|UNLV Rebels}} UNLV supports varsity teams in 17 different sports. The men's basketball team is referred to as the [[UNLV Runnin' Rebels basketball|Runnin' Rebels]] and the men's baseball team is referred to as the Hustlin' Rebels. The Rebels are a founding member of the [[Mountain West Conference]], in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA's]] Division I. The only exception is the UNLV men's soccer team, which competes in the [[Mountain Pacific Sports Federation]]. The school's official colors of scarlet and gray can be traced to the late-1950s when UNLV adopted as mascot a wolf wearing a Confederate uniform. Scarlet and Gray were traditional colors of the Confederacy with its gray uniforms and red-based flag. UNLV's mascot is Hey Reb, the toned down version of the original mascot named Beauregard, which was a wolf character dressed in [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] hat and uniform. UNLV's Hey Reb mascot made his debut in 1983. He received his first makeover in 1997 and second in 2009. Named one of 12 All-American Mascots, he competed for the title of 2004 Capital One Mascot of the Year and made a strong showing by coming in second in online voting. No stranger to national television, Hey Reb has also appeared in two memorable ESPN SportsCenter commercials. UNLV has many traditions in its athletic programs. Each year the men's football team plays the [[Nevada Wolf Pack]] in a football game called the [[Battle for Nevada]]. The trophy for that game is the [[Fremont Cannon]]. Built by the [[Kennecott Copper]] Corp., Nevada Mines Division, the cannon is valued at more than $10,000 and is considered one of the best, and loudest, symbols of rivalry in college football.http://unlvrebels.cstv.com/trads/unlv-trads-cannon.htmlhttp://unlvrebels.cstv.com/trads/unlv-trads-cannon.html UNLV is most known for its men's basketball program. Made famous by Coach [[Jerry Tarkanian]] in the 1970s–1990s, the Runnin' Rebels are the third most winning team in Division I basketball history by percentage, only behind Kentucky and North Carolina.(.713, 1037-418 through 2008)http://basketball.about.com/od/recordbook/a/winning-percent.htm UNLV is well known for their 1990 [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship]] by defeating [[Duke University]] 103-73, which was and still is the largest margin of victory in a championship game. In that same game, UNLV became the first team to ever break 100 points in a championship game.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1990_NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournamenthttp://unlvrebels.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/102909aaa.html UNLV is also well known for its golf program. Led by coach Dwaine Knight, the UNLV Golf program has turned out PGA Tour pros such as [[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]], [[Chris Riley (golfer)|Chris Riley]], [[Chad Campbell]], [[Ryan Moore (golfer)|Ryan Moore]], [[Skip Kendall]], [[Charlie Hoffman]], [[Bill Lunde]], and [[Andres Gonzales]].http://www.pgatour.com/players/02/97/20/ Andres Gonzales PGA Profile They won the NCAA National golf team championship in 1998. In February 2011, the Rebel men's swimming and diving team won their seventh straight Mountain West Conference titles.{{cite news|last=Wollard|first=Jeff|title=Expectations still high for UNLV swim team|url=http://www.lvrj.com/sports/expectations-still-high-132224383.html|accessdate=14 November 2011|newspaper=Las Vegas Review Journal|date=20 October 2011}} Three Rebel swimmers competed in the [[2008 Beijing Olympics]]; Joe Bartoch and Richard Hortness represented Canada and Jonas Anderson represented Sweden.{{cite web|last=Bevell|first=Shane|title=Back from Beijing: Rebel swimmers compete on the world's biggest sporting stage|url=http://magazine.unlv.edu/Issues/Fall08/12beijing.html|work=UNLV Magazine|accessdate=14 November 2011}} ==Faculty== Notable faculty include: *[[Maile Chapman]] *[[Hans-Hermann Hoppe]] *[[Michel Hugo]] *[[Claudia Keelan]] *[[Lawrence L. Larmore]] *[[Donald Revell]] *[[Willard Hughes Rollings]] *[[Murray Rothbard]] *[[Wole Soyinka]] *[[Randall Stout]] *[[Dina Titus]] *[[Michael Tylo]] *[[Douglas Unger|Douglas A. Unger]] *[[Richard Wiley]] ==Alumni== {{Main|List of University of Nevada, Las Vegas alumni}} UNLV has seen many of its former students go on to local and national prominence. This includes many athletes that have excelled at the collegiate and professional levels, including: *[[Greg Anthony]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/greg_anthony/bio.html|title=Greg Anthony Bio|publisher=National Basketball Association|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Stacey Augmon]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/stacey_augmon/bio.html|title=Stacey Augmon Bio|publisher=National Basketball Association|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Chad Campbell]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pgatour.com/players/01/25/10/|title=Chad Campbell's Official Profile|publisher=PGA Tour|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Randall Cunningham]]{{cite web|url=http://football.espn.go.com/nfl/players/profile?statsId=0066|title=Randall Cunningham Profile|publisher=ESPN.com|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Cecil Fielder]]{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/f/fieldce01.shtml|title=Cecil Fielder Statistics|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=2008-07-09}} * [[Joe Hawley]]{{cite web|url=http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/recruiting/player-Joe-Hawley-37603|title=Joe Hawley Recruiting Profile|publisher=rivals.com|accessdate=2011-10-13}} *[[Larry Johnson (basketball, born 1969)|Larry Johnson]]{{cite web|url=http://proxy.espn.go.com/chat/sportsnation/story?page=NCAA1991UNLV|title=ESPN:1991 UNLV Runnin' Rebels|publisher=ESPN SportsNation|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Ryan Ludwick]]{{cite web|url=http://stlouis.cardinals.mlb.com/team/player.jsp?player_id=407886|title=Player File - Ryan Ludwick|publisher=St. Louis Cardinals|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Shawn Marion]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/shawn_marion/bio.html|title=Shawn Marion Bio|publisher=National Basketball Association|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Keenan McCardell]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/players/keenanmccardell/profile?id=MCC170252|title=Keenan McCardell Bio|publisher=National Football League|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pgatour.com/players/02/45/02/|title=Adam Scott's Official Profile|publisher=PGA Tour|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Reggie Theus]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/coachfile/reggie_theus/|title=Reggie Theus|publisher=National Basketball Association|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Matt Williams (third baseman)|Matt Williams]]{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/w/willima04.shtml|title=Matt Williams Statistics|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=2008-07-09}} Former Rebels in the entertainment world include: *[[Chris Cox (DJ)]]{{cite web|url=http://www.motu.com/newsitems/chris-cox.html|title=Grammy-nominated producer/remixer/DJ Chris Cox makes Billboard history scoring hat trick with Kelly Osbourne Remix|publisher=MOTU|accessdate=2010-12-20}} *[[Guy Fieri]]{{cite web|url=http://www.guyfieri.com/guy_fieri_bio.pdf|format=PDF|title=Guy R. Fieri Bio|publisher=Guy Fieri|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Jimmy Kimmel]]{{cite news|last=Myerberg|first=Paul|title=The Quad Countdown: No. 111 U.N.L.V.|url=http://thequad.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/10/the-quad-countdown-no-111-unlv/|accessdate=25 July 2011|newspaper=New York Times|date=10 May 2008}} *[[Suge Knight]]{{cite web|url=http://hiphop.sh/suge|title=Suge Knight|publisher=HipHop.sh|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Kenny Mayne]]{{cite web|url=http://www.espnmediazone.com/bios/Talent/Mayne_Kenny.htm|title=Kenny Mayne|publisher=ESPN MediaZone|accessdate=2008-07-09 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080117072839/http://www.espnmediazone.com/bios/Talent/Mayne_Kenny.htm |archivedate = 2008-01-17}} *[[Tabitha D'umo|Tabitha]] and [[Napoleon D'umo]]Russell, Gregg. "Tabitha and Napoleon: Hip to Hip Hop." Studio Beat Fall 2006: 22-25.{{cite web|url=http://www.dance-teacher.com/content/hollywoods-hot-dancing-duo-tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo|title=Hollywood's Hot Dancing Duo, Tabitha and Napoleon D'Umo. Dance Teacher Magazine. By Jen Jones|accessdate=2011-06-28}} *[[Ronnie Vannucci]]{{cite web|url=http://zildjian.com/Artists/V/Ronnie-Vannucci|title=Ronnie Vannucci|publisher=Zildjian|accessdate=2011-07-15}} *[[Eric Whitacre]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ericwhitacre.com/main.html|title=The "Clarino" Interview|publisher=EricWhitacre.com|accessdate=2008-07-09}} *[[Anthony E. Zuiker]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2007/sep/19/qa-anthony-e-zuiker/|title=Q&A:Anthony E. Zuiker|publisher=Las Vegas Sun|accessdate=2008-07-09}} UNLV has also produced numerous politicians, including: * U.S. Congresswoman [[Shelley Berkley]]{{cite web|url=http://berkley.house.gov/services/resources/presskit/biography.html|title=Biography|publisher=Representative Shelley Berkley|accessdate=2008-07-09 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080625212225/http://berkley.house.gov/services/resources/presskit/biography.html |archivedate = 2008-06-25}} * U.S. Senator [[John Ensign]]{{cite web|url=http://ensign.senate.gov/about/about_index.htm|title=About Senator Ensign|publisher=John Ensign|accessdate=2008-07-09 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080704071251/http://ensign.senate.gov/about/about_index.htm |archivedate = 2008-07-04}} * [[Clark County, Nevada|Clark County]] District Attorney [[David Roger]]{{cite web|url=http://www.accessclarkcounty.com/depts/district_attorney/Pages/bio_david_roger.aspx/|title=David Roger Bio|publisher=Access Clark County|accessdate=2008-07-09}} Other notable alumni include: * Christian philosopher [[Francis J. Beckwith]]{{cite web|url=http://homepage.mac.com/francis.beckwith/bio.html|title=Biographical Sketch|publisher=Francis J. Beckwith|accessdate=2008-07-09 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080228212013/http://homepage.mac.com/francis.beckwith/bio.html |archivedate = 2008-02-28}} * President of Maloof Hotels and owner of the [[Sacramento Kings]] [[George J. Maloof, Jr.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.forbes.com/finance/mktguideapps/personinfo/FromPersonIdPersonTearsheet.jhtml?passedPersonId=1108209|title=Mr. George Maloof Jr. Profile|publisher=Forbes.com|accessdate=2008-07-09}} ==Gallery== File:unlv_1.jpg|Aerial view of the main campus File:unlv_3.jpg|The five-story Rod Lee Bigelow Health Sciences Building houses the offices, classrooms, and laboratories for [[health physics]], [[nursing]], [[radiological sciences]], [[physical therapy]], [[kinesiology]]. File:unlv_5.jpg|The glass wall of the [[Robert Bigelow|Robert L. Bigelow]] Physics Building was built in the shape of a sine wave, while banners inside represent the colors of the spectrum. File:unlv_6.jpg|The [[William S. Boyd School of Law|Boyd School of Law]] facilities include the state's largest law library and the Thomas and Mack Moot Court. File:unlv_7.jpg|UNLV's Science and Engineering Building (SEB). File:unlv_8.jpg|"The Flashlight" by renowned sculptor [[Claes Oldenburg]] stands 38 feet tall and symbolizes UNLV as a "Beacon of Knowledge" in Southern Nevada. File:unlv_9.jpg|UNLV's [[UNLV School of Dental Medicine|School of Dental Medicine]] is located in the heart of Las Vegas' medical district. In addition to training dental professionals, the school provides quality, low cost dental services to Southern Nevadans. File:unlv_17.jpg|Beam Hall is home to the colleges of Business and Hotel Administration. File:unlv_25.jpg|The University Libraries attracts scholars from around the globe with the most comprehensive collection of documents related to the history of gaming in the world. File:unlv_29.jpg|A view through the windows of Lied Library. The library holds more than a million volumes and has 2,500 study spaces. File:unlv_27.jpg|The Carol C. Harter Classroom Building Complex holds more classrooms than any other building on campus.
